packageMeta.name: purescript-uri
packageMeta.description: A type-safe parser, printer, and ADT for URLs and URIs.

declarations.comments:
A strictly absolute URI. An absolute URI can still contain relative paths
but is required to have a `Scheme` component.
declarations.title: AbsoluteURI

declarations.comments:
The authority part of a URI. For example: `purescript.org`,
`localhost:3000`, `user@example.net`.
declarations.title: Authority

declarations.comments: The fragment component (hash) of a URI.
declarations.title: Fragment

declarations.comments:
The "hierarchical part" of a generic or absolute URI. This combines an
authority (optional) with a path value.

When the authority is present a generic path representation can be used,
otherwise there are some restrictions on the path construction to ensure
no ambiguity in parsing (this is per the spec, not a restriction of the
library).
declarations.title: HierarchicalPart

declarations.comments:
The specific path types supported in a hierarchical-part when there is no
authority present. See [`URI.Path.Absolute`](../URI.Path.Absolute) and
[`URI.Path.Rootless`](../URI.Path.Rootless) for an explanation of these
forms.
declarations.title: HierPath

declarations.comments:
The reg-name variation of the host part of a URI. A reg-name is probably
more commonly referred to as just a host name or domain name (but it is
actually a name, rather than an IP address).
declarations.title: RegName

declarations.comments:
This type and parser are much too forgiving currently, allowing almost
anything through that looks vaguely IPv6ish.
declarations.title: IPv6Address

declarations.comments: The IPv4 address variation of the host part of a URI.
declarations.title: IPv4Address

declarations.comments: A host address. Supports named addresses, IPv4, and IPv6.
declarations.title: Host

declarations.comments:
A generic absolute-or-empty path, used in both hierarchical-part and
relative-parts when an authority component is present. Corresponds to
_path-abempty_ in the spec.

A path value of `/` corresponds to `Path [""]`, an empty path is `Path []`.
declarations.title: Path

declarations.comments:
An absolute path, corresponding to _path-absolute_ in the spec. This path
cannot represent the value `//` - it must either be `/`, or start with a
segment that is not empty, for example: `/something`, `/.`, `/..`. This
type can appear in both hierarchical-part and relative-parts to represent
an absolute path when no authority component is present.

This restriction exists as a value begining with `//` at this point in the
grammar must be an authority, attempting to decide whether a value is an
authority or a path would be ambiguous if `//` paths were allowed. The `//`
path means the same thing as `/` anyway!
declarations.title: PathAbsolute

declarations.comments:
A relative path that doesn't look like a URI scheme, corresponding to
_path-noscheme_ in the spec. This path cannot start with the character
`/`, contain the character `:` before the first `/`, or be entirely empty.
This type can appear in a relative-part when there is no authority
component.
declarations.title: PathNoScheme

declarations.comments:
A relative path, corresponding to _path-rootless_ in the spec. This path
cannot start with the character `/` or be entirely empty. This type can
appear in a hierarchical-part when there is no authority component.
declarations.title: PathRootless

declarations.comments: The port component of a host in a URI.
declarations.title: Port

declarations.comments:
The query component of a URI.

This type treats the entire string as an undifferentiated blob, if you
would like to deal with the common `?key1=value1&key2=value2` format, take
a look at `URI.Extra.QueryPairs`.
declarations.title: Query

declarations.comments:
The "relative part" of a relative reference.  This combines an authority
(optional) with a path value.

When the authority is present a generic path representation can be used,
otherwise there are some restrictions on the path construction to ensure
no ambiguity in parsing (this is per the spec, not a restriction of the
library).
declarations.title: RelativePart

declarations.comments:
The specific path types supported in a relative-part when there is no
authority present. See [`URI.Path.Absolute`](../URI.Path.Absolute) and
[`URI.Path.PathNoScheme`](../URI.Path.PathNoScheme) for an explanation of
these forms.
declarations.title: RelPath

declarations.comments: A relative URI. Relative in the sense that it lacks a `Scheme` component.
declarations.title: RelativeRef

declarations.comments: The scheme part of an absolute URI. For example: `http`, `ftp`, `git`.
declarations.title: Scheme

declarations.comments:
A general purpose absolute URI - similar to `AbsoluteURI` but also admits
a fragment component. An absolute URI can still contain relative paths
but is required to have a `Scheme` component.
declarations.title: URI

declarations.comments: The most general kind of URI, can either be relative or absolute.
declarations.title: URIRef

declarations.comments:
The user info part of an `Authority`. For example: `user`, `foo:bar`.

This type treats the entire string as an undifferentiated blob, if you
would like to specifically deal with the `user:password` format, take a
look at `URI.Extra.UserPassInfo`.
declarations.title: UserInfo

declarations.comments:
The user info part of an `Authority`. For example: `user`, `foo:bar`.

This type treats the entire string as an undifferentiated blob, if you
would like to specifically deal with the `user:password` format, take a
look at `URI.Extra.UserPassInfo`.
declarations.title: UserInfo

declarations.comments:
The reg-name variation of the host part of a URI. A reg-name is probably
more commonly referred to as just a host name or domain name (but it is
actually a name, rather than an IP address).
declarations.title: RegName

declarations.comments: The port component of a host in a URI.
declarations.title: Port

declarations.comments:
A relative path, corresponding to _path-rootless_ in the spec. This path
cannot start with the character `/` or be entirely empty. This type can
appear in a hierarchical-part when there is no authority component.
declarations.title: PathRootless

declarations.comments:
An absolute path, corresponding to _path-absolute_ in the spec. This path
cannot represent the value `//` - it must either be `/`, or start with a
segment that is not empty, for example: `/something`, `/.`, `/..`. This
type can appear in both hierarchical-part and relative-parts to represent

This restriction exists as a value begining with `//` at this point in the

declarations.title: PathAbsolute

declarations.comments:
A generic absolute-or-empty path, used in both hierarchical-part and
relative-parts when an authority component is present. Corresponds to
_path-abempty_ in the spec.

A path value of `/` corresponds to `Path [""]`, an empty path is `Path []`.
declarations.title: Path

declarations.comments:
This type and parser are much too forgiving currently, allowing almost
anything through that looks vaguely IPv6ish.
declarations.title: IPv6Address

declarations.comments: The IPv4 address variation of the host part of a URI.
declarations.title: IPv4Address

declarations.comments: A host address. Supports named addresses, IPv4, and IPv6.
declarations.title: Host

declarations.comments:
A row type for describing the options fields used by the hierarchical-part
printer.

Used as `Record (HierarchicalPartPrintOptions userInfo hosts path hierPath ())`
when type anotating an options record.
declarations.title: HierarchicalPartPrintOptions

declarations.comments:
A row type for describing the options fields used by the hierarchical-part
parser.

Used as `Record (HierarchicalPartParseOptions userInfo hosts path hierPath ())`
when type anotating an options record.
declarations.title: HierarchicalPartParseOptions

declarations.comments:
A row type for describing the options fields used by the hierarchical-part
parser and printer.

Used as `Record (HierarchicalPartOptions userInfo hosts path hierPath)`
when type anotating an options record.
declarations.title: HierarchicalPartOptions

declarations.comments:
The "hierarchical part" of a generic or absolute URI. This combines an
authority (optional) with a path value.

When the authority is present a generic path representation can be used,
otherwise there are some restrictions on the path construction to ensure
no ambiguity in parsing (this is per the spec, not a restriction of the

declarations.title: HierarchicalPart

declarations.comments:
The specific path types supported in a hierarchical-part when there is no
authority present. See [`URI.Path.Absolute`](../URI.Path.Absolute) and

declarations.title: HierPath

declarations.comments:
A row type for describing the options fields used by the authority printer.

Used as `Record (AuthorityPrintOptions userInfo hosts ())` when type
annotating an options record.
declarations.title: AuthorityPrintOptions

declarations.comments:
A row type for describing the options fields used by the authority parser.

Used as `Record (AuthorityParseOptions userInfo hosts ())` when type
annotating an options record.
declarations.title: AuthorityParseOptions

declarations.comments:
A row type for describing the options fields used by the authority parser
and printer.

Used as `Record (AuthorityOptions userInfo hosts)` when type annotating an
options record.
declarations.title: AuthorityOptions

declarations.comments:
The authority part of a URI. For example: `purescript.org`,
`localhost:3000`, `user@example.net`.
declarations.title: Authority

declarations.comments: A lens for the user-info component of the authority.
declarations.title: _userInfo

declarations.comments:
An affine traversal for the path component of a hierarchical-part, this
succeeds when the authority is present also.
declarations.title: _path

declarations.comments: A lens for the host(s) component of the authority.
declarations.title: _hosts

declarations.comments:
An affine traversal for the path component of a hierarchical-part, this
succeeds when the authority is not present.
declarations.title: _hierPath

declarations.comments: An affine traversal for the authority component of a hierarchical-part.
declarations.title: _authority

declarations.comments: A prism for the `NameAddress` constructor.
declarations.title: _NameAddress

declarations.comments: A prism for the `IPv6Address` constructor.
declarations.title: _IPv6Address

declarations.comments: A prism for the `IPv4Address` constructor.
declarations.title: _IPv4Address

declarations.comments:
The query component of a URI.

This type treats the entire string as an undifferentiated blob, if you

declarations.comments: The scheme part of an absolute URI. For example: `http`, `ftp`, `git`.
declarations.title: Scheme

declarations.comments:
A strictly absolute URI. An absolute URI can still contain relative paths
but is required to have a `Scheme` component.
declarations.title: AbsoluteURI

declarations.comments:
A row type for describing the options fields used by the absolute URI
parser and printer.

Used as `Record (AbsoluteURIOptions userInfo hosts path hierPath query)`
when type anotating an options record.

See below for details of how to use these configuration options.
declarations.title: AbsoluteURIOptions

declarations.comments:
A row type for describing the options fields used by the absolute URI
parser.

Used as `Record (AbsoluteURIParseOptions userInfo hosts path hierPath query ())`
when type anotating an options record.

Having this options record allows custom representations to be used for
the URI components. If this is not necessary, `pure` can be used for all
the options aside from `parseHosts`, which will typically be
`HostPortPair.parseHosts pure pure`. See [`URI.HostPortPair`](../URI.HostPortPair)
for more information on the host/port pair parser.
declarations.title: AbsoluteURIParseOptions

declarations.comments:
A row type for describing the options fields used by the absolute URI
printer.

Used as `Record (AbsoluteURIPrintOptions userInfo hosts path hierPath query ())`
when type anotating an options record.

As a reverse of the parse options, this specifies how to print values back
from custom representations. If this is not necessary, `identity` can be used for
all the options aside from `printHosts`, which will typically be
`HostPortPair.printHosts identity identity`. See [`URI.HostPortPair`](../URI.HostPortPair)
for more information on the host/port pair printer.
declarations.title: AbsoluteURIPrintOptions

declarations.comments: A parser for an absolute URI.
declarations.title: parser

declarations.comments: A printer for an absolute URI.
declarations.title: print

declarations.comments: The query component of an absolute URI.

declarations.title: Authority

declarations.comments:
A row type for describing the options fields used by the authority parser

Used as `Record (AuthorityOptions userInfo hosts)` when type annotating an

declarations.comments:
A parser for the authority part of a URI. Expects values with a `"//"`
prefix.
declarations.title: parser

declarations.comments:
A printer for the authority part of a URI. Will print the value with a
`"//"` prefix.
declarations.title: print

declarations.comments: A lens for the user-info component of the authority.
declarations.title: _userInfo

declarations.comments: A lens for the host(s) component of the authority.

modules.name: URI.Common
modules.comments: Common functions used in parsing and printing URI components.

declarations.comments: An error type used when a custom component parser fails to handle a value.
declarations.title: URIPartParseError

declarations.comments:
Adapts a parser with a parser-esque function. First the original
parser runs, then it attempts to refine the result with the function.
declarations.title: wrapParser

declarations.comments: Parser for ascii alphabetical characters (upper and lowercase).
declarations.title: alpha

declarations.comments: Parser for ascii alphanumeric characters (upper and lowercase for letters).
declarations.title: alphaNum

declarations.comments:
Parser for characters that are allowed in a URI but do not have a reserved
purpose.
declarations.title: unreserved

declarations.comments: Parser for a percent-encoded character.
declarations.title: pctEncoded

declarations.comments: Parser for the "sub-delims" group of reserved characters.
declarations.title: subDelims

declarations.comments:
A helper function for printing URI components using percent-encoding for
characters that require it.

Accepts a parser that is used to determine whether a character is allowed
to appear un-encoded in the URI component and the string to encode.
declarations.title: printEncoded

declarations.comments:
A version of [`printEncoded`](#v:printEncoded) that operates on non-empty
strings.
declarations.title: printEncoded'

declarations.comments:
A version of [`decodeURIComponent`](https://pursuit.purescript.org/packages/purescript-jsuri/docs/JSURI#v:decodeURIComponent)
that operates on non-empty strings.
declarations.title: decodeURIComponent'

declarations.comments:
Multi-host/port pairs, where host & port combinations can be separated by
`,`, as used by some connection URI schemes. This is not strictly
compatible with RFC 3986, as in that spec `RegName`s can contain `,`, and
only one port can be specified in the authority.

A motivating example for where this may be useful: dealing with mongodb
connection strings.
declarations.title: MultiHostPortPair

declarations.comments:
A parser for multiple host/port pairs embedded in a URI.

This function allows for the `Host` and `Port` components to be parsed into
custom representations. If this is not necessary, use `pure` for both of
these arguments.
declarations.title: parser

declarations.comments:
A printer for multiple host/port pairs embedded in a URI.

As a counterpart to the `parser` this function also requires the `Host`
and `Port` components to be printed back from their custom representations.
If no custom types are being used, pass `identity` for both of these arguments.
declarations.title: print

declarations.comments:
A query string split into an array of key/value pairs. There is no precise
spec for this, but the format is commonly used, so this attempts to handle
these strings in a sensible way.

- The representation uses an array rather than a map, so duplicate keys
  are supported.
- Keys are not required to have a value associated.
- `&` and `;` are both treated as pair delimiters.
declarations.title: QueryPairs

declarations.comments:
Parses a query into key/value pairs.

This function allows for the `Key` and `Value` components to be parsed
into custom representations. If this is not necessary, use `pure` for both
these arguments.
declarations.title: parse

declarations.comments:
A printer for key/value pairs style query string.

As a counterpart to the `parser` this function also requires the `Key`
and `Value` components to be printed back from their custom representations.
If no custom types are being used, pass `identity` for both of these arguments.
declarations.title: print

declarations.comments: The supported key characters, excluding percent-encodings.
declarations.title: keyPartChar

declarations.comments: The supported value characters, excluding percent-encodings.
declarations.title: valuePartChar

declarations.comments: The default `Key` type used for `QueryPairs`.
declarations.title: Key

declarations.comments:
Constructs a key value from a string, percent-encoding any characters
that require it. Note that running this on a string that has already had
percent-encoding applied will double-encode it, for those situations use
`unsafeKeyFromString` instead.

``` purescript
keyFromString "foo" = unsafeKeyFromString "foo"
keyFromString "foo#bar" = unsafeKeyFromString "foo%23bar"
keyFromString "foo%23bar" = unsafeKeyFromString "foo%2523bar"
```
declarations.title: keyFromString

declarations.comments:
Returns the string value for a key, percent-decoding any characters
that require it.

``` purescript
keyToString (unsafeKeyFromString "foo") = "foo"
keyToString (unsafeKeyFromString "foo%23bar") = "foo#bar"
```
declarations.title: keyToString

declarations.comments:
Constructs a key value from a string directly - no percent-encoding
will be applied. This is useful when using a custom encoding scheme for
the key, to prevent double-encoding.
declarations.title: unsafeKeyFromString

declarations.comments:
Returns the string value for a key without percent-decoding. Only
"unsafe" in the sense that values this produces may need further decoding,
the name is more for symmetry with the `fromString`/`unsafeFromString`
pairing.
declarations.title: unsafeKeyToString

declarations.comments: The default `Value` type used for `QueryPairs`.
declarations.title: Value

declarations.comments:
Constructs a value from a string, percent-encoding any characters
that require it. Note that running this on a string that has already had
percent-encoding applied will double-encode it, for those situations use
`unsafeValueFromString` instead.

``` purescript
valueFromString "foo" = unsafeValueFromString "foo"
valueFromString "foo#bar" = unsafeValueFromString "foo%23bar"
valueFromString "foo%23bar" = unsafeValueFromString "foo%2523bar"
```
declarations.title: valueFromString

declarations.comments:
Returns the string value for a value, percent-decoding any characters
that require it.

``` purescript
valueToString (unsafeValueFromString "foo") = "foo"
valueToString (unsafeValueFromString "foo%23bar") = "foo#bar"
```
declarations.title: valueToString

declarations.comments:
Constructs a value from a string directly - no percent-encoding
will be applied. This is useful when using a custom encoding scheme for
the value, to prevent double-encoding.
declarations.title: unsafeValueFromString

declarations.comments:
Returns the string value for a value without percent-decoding. Only
"unsafe" in the sense that values this produces may need further decoding,
the name is more for symmetry with the `fromString`/`unsafeFromString`
pairing.
declarations.title: unsafeValueToString

declarations.comments:
`user:password` formatted user-info components for URI authorities.

This format is considered deprecated according to RFC3986 but is still
very common, so this is provided for cases where it is necessary.

The username part is required, so a value like `:hello` will fail to parse
for this type.

The `:` characer will be percent-encoded in all locations other than the
`user:password` separator, although the parser will accept passwords
containing un-encoded `:` characters.
declarations.title: UserPassInfo

declarations.comments: A parser for `user:password` formatted user-info.
declarations.title: parse

declarations.comments: A printer for `user:password` formatted user-info.
declarations.title: print

declarations.comments: The supported user/password characters, excluding percent-encodings.
declarations.title: userPassInfoChar

declarations.comments: The fragment component (hash) of a URI.
declarations.title: Fragment

declarations.comments:
Constructs a fragment value from a string, percent-encoding any characters
that require it. Note that running this on a string that has already had
percent-encoding applied will double-encode it, for those situations use
`unsafeFromString` instead.

``` purescript
fromString "foo" = unsafeFromString "foo"
fromString "foo#bar" = unsafeFromString "foo%23bar"
fromString "foo%23bar" = unsafeFromString "foo%2523bar"
```
declarations.title: fromString

declarations.comments:
Returns the string value for a fragment, percent-decoding any characters
that require it.

``` purescript
toString (unsafeFromString "foo") = "foo"
toString (unsafeFromString "foo%23bar") = "foo#bar"
```
declarations.title: toString

declarations.comments:
Constructs a fragment value from a string directly - no percent-encoding
will be applied. This is useful when using a custom encoding scheme for
the fragment, to prevent double-encoding.
declarations.title: unsafeFromString

declarations.comments:
Returns the string value for the fragment without percent-decoding. Only
"unsafe" in the sense that values this produces may need further decoding,
the name is more for symmetry with the `fromString`/`unsafeFromString`
pairing.
declarations.title: unsafeToString

declarations.comments:
A parser for the fragment component of a URI. Expects values with a `'#'`
prefix.
declarations.title: parser

declarations.comments:
A printer for the fragment component of a URI. Will print the value with
a `'#'` prefix.
declarations.title: print

declarations.comments: The supported fragment characters, excluding percent-encodings.
declarations.title: fragmentChar

declarations.comments:
The user info part of an `Authority`. For example: `user`, `foo:bar`.

This type treats the entire string as an undifferentiated blob, if you
would like to specifically deal with the `user:password` format, take a
look at `URI.Extra.UserPassInfo`.

A row type for describing the options fields used by the authority printer.

Used as `Record (AuthorityPrintOptions userInfo hosts ())` when type

declarations.comments:
A row type for describing the options fields used by the authority parser.

authority (optional) with a path value.

When the authority is present a generic path representation can be used,
otherwise there are some restrictions on the path construction to ensure
no ambiguity in parsing (this is per the spec, not a restriction of the
library).
declarations.title: HierarchicalPart

declarations.comments:
A row type for describing the options fields used by the hierarchical-part
parser and printer.

Used as `Record (HierarchicalPartOptions userInfo hosts path hierPath)`
when type anotating an options record.
declarations.title: HierarchicalPartOptions

declarations.comments:
A row type for describing the options fields used by the hierarchical-part
parser.

Used as `Record (HierarchicalPartParseOptions userInfo hosts path hierPath ())`
when type anotating an options record.
declarations.title: HierarchicalPartParseOptions

declarations.comments:
A row type for describing the options fields used by the hierarchical-part
printer.

Used as `Record (HierarchicalPartPrintOptions userInfo hosts path hierPath ())`
when type anotating an options record.
declarations.title: HierarchicalPartPrintOptions

declarations.comments:
The specific path types supported in a hierarchical-part when there is no
authority present. See [`URI.Path.Absolute`](../URI.Path.Absolute) and
[`URI.Path.Rootless`](../URI.Path.Rootless) for an explanation of these
forms.
declarations.title: HierPath

declarations.comments: A parser for the hierarchical-part of a URI.
declarations.title: parser

declarations.comments: A printer for the hierarchical-part of a URI.

declarations.title: _authority

declarations.comments:
An affine traversal for the path component of a hierarchical-part, this
succeeds when the authority is present also.

declarations.comments:
An affine traversal for the path component of a hierarchical-part, this
succeeds when the authority is not present.

declarations.comments:
This type and parser are much too forgiving currently, allowing almost
anything through that looks vaguely IPv6ish.

declarations.comments:
The reg-name variation of the host part of a URI. A reg-name is probably
more commonly referred to as just a host name or domain name (but it is

declarations.title: IPv4Address

declarations.comments:
Constructs a `IPv4Address` part safely: bounds-checks each octet to ensure
it occurs within the range 0-255 (inclusive).
declarations.title: fromInts

declarations.comments:
Constructs a `IPv4Address` part unsafely: if any of the arguments are
outside the allowable bounds, a runtime error will be thrown.

This is intended as a convenience when describing `IPv4Address`es
statically in PureScript code, in all other cases `fromInts` should be
used.
declarations.title: unsafeFromInts

declarations.comments:
This type and parser are much too forgiving currently, allowing almost
anything through that looks vaguely IPv6ish.

declarations.comments:
The reg-name variation of the host part of a URI. A reg-name is probably
more commonly referred to as just a host name or domain name (but it is
actually a name, rather than an IP address).
declarations.title: RegName

declarations.comments:
Constructs a reg-name value from a string, percent-encoding any characters
that require it. Note that running this on a string that has already had
percent-encoding applied will double-encode it, for those situations use
`unsafeFromString` instead.

``` purescript
fromString "foo.com" = unsafeFromString "foo.com"
fromString "foo:bar" = unsafeFromString "foo%3Abar"
fromString "foo%3Abar" = unsafeFromString "foo%253Abar"
```
declarations.title: fromString

declarations.comments:
Returns the string value for a reg-name, percent-decoding any characters
that require it.

``` purescript
toString (unsafeFromString "foo.com") = "foo.com"
toString (unsafeFromString "foo%3Abar") = "foo:bar"
```
declarations.title: toString

declarations.comments:
Constructs a query value from a string directly - no percent-encoding
will be applied. This is useful when using a custom encoding scheme for
the query, to prevent double-encoding.
declarations.title: unsafeFromString

declarations.comments:
Returns the string value for the reg-name without percent-decoding. Only
"unsafe" in the sense that values this produces may need further decoding,
the name is more for symmetry with the `fromString`/`unsafeFromString`
pairing.
declarations.title: unsafeToString

declarations.comments: A parser for reg-names.
declarations.title: parser

declarations.comments: A printer for reg-names.
declarations.title: print

declarations.comments: The supported reg-name characters, excluding percent-encodings.
declarations.title: regNameChar

declarations.comments:
A spec-conformant host/port pair (may also be empty).
For example: `purescript.org`, `localhost:3000`, `:9000`.
declarations.title: HostPortPair

declarations.comments:
A parser for a spec-conformant host/port pair.

This function allows for the `Host` and `Port` components to be parsed into
custom representations. If this is not necessary, use `pure` for both of
these arguments.

Host parsing is dealt with a little differently to all the other URI
components, as for hosts the control is passed entirely to the component
parser. This is to accomodate multi-host URIs that are used sometimes for
connection strings and the like, but as these are not spec-conforming this
part of parsing may need to bend the rules a little. See
[`URI.Extra.MultiHostPortPair`](../URI.Extra.MultiHostPortPair) for an
example of this.
declarations.title: parser

declarations.comments:
A printer for a spec-conformant host/port pair.

As a counterpart to the `parser` this function also requires the `Host`
and `Port` components to be printed back from their custom representations.
If no custom types are being used, pass `identity` for both of these arguments.
declarations.title: print

declarations.comments: Generates a random `RegName` for testing purposes.
declarations.title: genRegName

declarations.comments: Generates a random `IPv4Address` for testing purposes.

declarations.comments:
A generic absolute-or-empty path, used in both hierarchical-part and
relative-parts when an authority component is present. Corresponds to
_path-abempty_ in the spec.

A path value of `/` corresponds to `Path [""]`, an empty path is `Path []`.

declarations.comments: A parser for a _path-abempty_ URI component.
declarations.title: parser

declarations.comments: A printer for a _path-abempty_ URI component.
declarations.title: print

declarations.comments:
An absolute path, corresponding to _path-absolute_ in the spec. This path
cannot represent the value `//` - it must either be `/`, or start with a
segment that is not empty, for example: `/something`, `/.`, `/..`. This
type can appear in both hierarchical-part and relative-parts to represent
an absolute path when no authority component is present.

This restriction exists as a value begining with `//` at this point in the
grammar must be an authority, attempting to decide whether a value is an
authority or a path would be ambiguous if `//` paths were allowed. The `//`
path means the same thing as `/` anyway!
declarations.title: PathAbsolute

declarations.comments: A parser for a _path-absolute_ URI component.
declarations.title: parse

declarations.comments: A printer for a _path-absolute_ URI component.
declarations.title: print

declarations.comments:
A relative path that doesn't look like a URI scheme, corresponding to
_path-noscheme_ in the spec. This path cannot start with the character
`/`, contain the character `:` before the first `/`, or be entirely empty.
This type can appear in a relative-part when there is no authority
component.

declarations.comments: A printer for a _path-noscheme_ URI component.

declarations.comments: A printer for a _path-rootless_ URI component.
declarations.title: print

declarations.comments:

contains multiple contiguous slashes this is represented by a group of

declarations.comments: Returns the port number as an integer.

Attempts to create a port from the passed integer. If the value falls
outside of the range 0-65535 (inclusive) `Nothing` will be returned.

acceptable port number a runtime error will be thrown.

PureScript code, in all other cases `fromInt` should be preferred.


declarations.comments:
Returns the string value for a query, percent-decoding any characters
that require it.

``` purescript
toString (unsafeFromString "foo") = "foo"
toString (unsafeFromString "foo%23bar") = "foo#bar"
```

Constructs a query value from a string directly - no percent-encoding

declarations.comments:

`localhost:3000`, `user@example.net`.
declarations.title: Authority

declarations.comments: A lens for the user-info component of the authority.
declarations.title: _userInfo

declarations.comments:
An affine traversal for the path component of a relative-part, this
succeeds when the authority is not present.
declarations.title: _relPath

declarations.comments:
An affine traversal for the path component of a relative-part, this
succeeds when the authority is present also.
declarations.title: _path

declarations.comments: A lens for the host(s) component of the authority.
declarations.title: _hosts

declarations.comments: An affine traversal for the authority component of a relative-part.
declarations.title: _authority

declarations.comments: A prism for the `NameAddress` constructor.
declarations.title: _NameAddress

declarations.comments: A prism for the `IPv6Address` constructor.
declarations.title: _IPv6Address

declarations.comments: A prism for the `IPv4Address` constructor.
declarations.title: _IPv4Address

declarations.comments: A relative URI. Relative in the sense that it lacks a `Scheme` component.
declarations.title: RelativeRef

declarations.comments:
A row type for describing the options fields used by the relative URI
parser and printer.

Used as `Record (RelativeRefOptions userInfo hosts path relPath query fragment)`
when type anotating an options record.

See below for details of how to use these configuration options.
declarations.title: RelativeRefOptions

declarations.comments:
A row type for describing the options fields used by the relative URI
parser.

Used as `Record (RelativeRefParseOptions userInfo hosts path relPath query fragment ())`
when type anotating an options record.

Having this options record allows custom representations to be used for
the URI components. If this is not necessary, `pure` can be used for all
the options aside from `parseHosts`, which will typically be
`HostPortPair.parseHosts pure pure`. See [`URI.HostPortPair`](../URI.HostPortPair)
for more information on the host/port pair parser.
declarations.title: RelativeRefParseOptions

declarations.comments:
A row type for describing the options fields used by the relative URI
printer.

As a reverse of the parse options, this specifies how to print values back
from custom representations. If this is not necessary, `identity` can be used for
all the options aside from `printHosts`, which will typically be
`HostPortPair.printHosts identity identity`. See [`URI.HostPortPair`](../URI.HostPortPair)
for more information on the host/port pair printer.
declarations.title: RelativeRefPrintOptions

declarations.comments: A parser for a relative URI.
declarations.title: parser

declarations.comments: A printer for a relative URI.
declarations.title: print

declarations.comments: The relative-part component of a relative URI.
declarations.title: _relPart

declarations.comments: The query component of a relative URI.
declarations.title: _query

declarations.comments: The fragment component of a relative URI.
declarations.title: _fragment

declarations.comments: The scheme part of an absolute URI. For example: `http`, `ftp`, `git`.
declarations.title: Scheme

declarations.comments:
Attempts to create a `Scheme` from the passed string. The scheme component
of a URI has no escape sequences, so this function will return `Nothing`
if an invalid value is provided.

``` purescript
fromString "http" == Just (Scheme.unsafeFromString "http")
fromString "git+ssh" == Just (Scheme.unsafeFromString "git+ssh")
fromString "!!!" == Nothing
fromString "" == Nothing
```
declarations.title: fromString

declarations.comments:
Returns the string value for a scheme.

``` purescript
toString (unsafeFromString "http") == "http"
toString (unsafeFromString "git+ssh") == "git+ssh"
```
declarations.title: toString

declarations.comments:
Constructs a `Scheme` part unsafely: if the value is not an acceptable
scheme a runtime error will be thrown.

This is intended as a convenience when describing `Scheme`s statically in
PureScript code, in all other cases `fromString` should be used.
declarations.title: unsafeFromString

declarations.comments:
A parser for the scheme component of a URI. Expects a scheme string
followed by `':'`.
declarations.title: parser

declarations.comments:
A printer for the scheme component of a URI. Prints a scheme value
followed by a `':'`.
declarations.title: print

declarations.comments:
The user info part of an `Authority`. For example: `user`, `foo:bar`.

This type treats the entire string as an undifferentiated blob, if you
would like to specifically deal with the `user:password` format, take a
look at `URI.Extra.UserPassInfo`.
declarations.title: UserInfo

declarations.comments:
The reg-name variation of the host part of a URI. A reg-name is probably
more commonly referred to as just a host name or domain name (but it is
actually a name, rather than an IP address).
declarations.title: RegName

declarations.comments: The port component of a host in a URI.
declarations.title: Port

declarations.comments:
A relative path, corresponding to _path-rootless_ in the spec. This path
cannot start with the character `/` or be entirely empty. This type can
appear in a hierarchical-part when there is no authority component.
declarations.title: PathRootless

declarations.comments:
An absolute path, corresponding to _path-absolute_ in the spec. This path
cannot represent the value `//` - it must either be `/`, or start with a
segment that is not empty, for example: `/something`, `/.`, `/..`. This
type can appear in both hierarchical-part and relative-parts to represent
an absolute path when no authority component is present.

This restriction exists as a value begining with `//` at this point in the
grammar must be an authority, attempting to decide whether a value is an
authority or a path would be ambiguous if `//` paths were allowed. The `//`
path means the same thing as `/` anyway!
declarations.title: PathAbsolute

declarations.comments:
A generic absolute-or-empty path, used in both hierarchical-part and
relative-parts when an authority component is present. Corresponds to
_path-abempty_ in the spec.

A path value of `/` corresponds to `Path [""]`, an empty path is `Path []`.
declarations.title: Path

declarations.comments:
This type and parser are much too forgiving currently, allowing almost
anything through that looks vaguely IPv6ish.
declarations.title: IPv6Address

declarations.comments: The IPv4 address variation of the host part of a URI.
declarations.title: IPv4Address

declarations.comments: A host address. Supports named addresses, IPv4, and IPv6.
declarations.title: Host

declarations.comments:
A row type for describing the options fields used by the hierarchical-part
printer.

Used as `Record (HierarchicalPartPrintOptions userInfo hosts path hierPath ())`
when type anotating an options record.
declarations.title: HierarchicalPartPrintOptions

declarations.comments:
A row type for describing the options fields used by the hierarchical-part
parser.

Used as `Record (HierarchicalPartParseOptions userInfo hosts path hierPath ())`
when type anotating an options record.
declarations.title: HierarchicalPartParseOptions

declarations.comments:
A row type for describing the options fields used by the hierarchical-part
parser and printer.

Used as `Record (HierarchicalPartOptions userInfo hosts path hierPath)`
when type anotating an options record.
declarations.title: HierarchicalPartOptions

declarations.comments:
The "hierarchical part" of a generic or absolute URI. This combines an
authority (optional) with a path value.

When the authority is present a generic path representation can be used,
otherwise there are some restrictions on the path construction to ensure
no ambiguity in parsing (this is per the spec, not a restriction of the
library).
declarations.title: HierarchicalPart

declarations.comments:
The specific path types supported in a hierarchical-part when there is no
authority present. See [`URI.Path.Absolute`](../URI.Path.Absolute) and
[`URI.Path.Rootless`](../URI.Path.Rootless) for an explanation of these
forms.
declarations.title: HierPath

declarations.comments:
A row type for describing the options fields used by the authority printer.

Used as `Record (AuthorityPrintOptions userInfo hosts ())` when type
annotating an options record.
declarations.title: AuthorityPrintOptions

declarations.comments:
A row type for describing the options fields used by the authority parser.

Used as `Record (AuthorityParseOptions userInfo hosts ())` when type
annotating an options record.
declarations.title: AuthorityParseOptions

declarations.comments:
A row type for describing the options fields used by the authority parser
and printer.

Used as `Record (AuthorityOptions userInfo hosts)` when type annotating an
options record.
declarations.title: AuthorityOptions

declarations.comments:
The authority part of a URI. For example: `purescript.org`,
`localhost:3000`, `user@example.net`.
declarations.title: Authority

declarations.title: _userInfo

An affine traversal for the path component of a hierarchical-part, this

declarations.title: _hosts

An affine traversal for the path component of a hierarchical-part, this

declarations.comments: An affine traversal for the authority component of a hierarchical-part.
declarations.title: _authority

declarations.comments:
The query component of a URI.

This type treats the entire string as an undifferentiated blob, if you
would like to deal with the common `?key1=value1&key2=value2` format, take
a look at `URI.Extra.QueryPairs`.
declarations.title: Query

declarations.comments: The scheme part of an absolute URI. For example: `http`, `ftp`, `git`.
declarations.title: Scheme

declarations.comments:
A general purpose absolute URI - similar to `AbsoluteURI` but also admits
a fragment component. An absolute URI can still contain relative paths
but is required to have a `Scheme` component.
declarations.title: URI

declarations.comments:
A row type for describing the options fields used by the URI parser and
printer.

Used as `Record (URIOptions userInfo hosts path hierPath query fragment)`
when type anotating an options record.

See below for details of how to use these configuration options.
declarations.title: URIOptions

declarations.comments:
A row type for describing the options fields used by the URI parser.

Used as `Record (URIParseOptions userInfo hosts path hierPath query fragment ())`
when type anotating an options record.

Having this options record allows custom representations to be used for
the URI components. If this is not necessary, `pure` can be used for all
the options aside from `parseHosts`, which will typically be
`HostPortPair.parseHosts pure pure`. See [`URI.HostPortPair`](../URI.HostPortPair)
for more information on the host/port pair parser.
declarations.title: URIParseOptions

declarations.comments:
A row type for describing the options fields used by the URI printer.

Used as `Record (URIPrintOptions userInfo hosts path hierPath query fragment ())`
when type anotating an options record.

As a reverse of the parse options, this specifies how to print values back
from custom representations. If this is not necessary, `identity` can be used for
all the options aside from `printHosts`, which will typically be
`HostPortPair.printHosts identity identity`. See [`URI.HostPortPair`](../URI.HostPortPair)
for more information on the host/port pair printer.
declarations.title: URIPrintOptions

declarations.comments: A parser for a URI.
declarations.title: parser

declarations.comments: A printer for a URI.
declarations.title: print

declarations.comments: The scheme component of a URI.
declarations.title: _scheme

declarations.comments: The hierarchical-part component of a URI.
declarations.title: _hierPart

declarations.comments: The query component of a URI.
declarations.title: _query

declarations.comments: The fragment component of a URI.
declarations.title: _fragment

declarations.comments:
The authority part of a URI. For example: `purescript.org`,
`localhost:3000`, `user@example.net`.
declarations.title: Authority

declarations.comments: The fragment component (hash) of a URI.
declarations.title: Fragment

declarations.comments:
The reg-name variation of the host part of a URI. A reg-name is probably
more commonly referred to as just a host name or domain name (but it is
actually a name, rather than an IP address).
declarations.title: RegName

declarations.comments:
This type and parser are much too forgiving currently, allowing almost
anything through that looks vaguely IPv6ish.
declarations.title: IPv6Address

declarations.comments: The IPv4 address variation of the host part of a URI.
declarations.title: IPv4Address

declarations.comments: A host address. Supports named addresses, IPv4, and IPv6.
declarations.title: Host

declarations.comments: A prism for the `NameAddress` constructor.
declarations.title: _NameAddress

declarations.comments: A prism for the `IPv6Address` constructor.
declarations.title: _IPv6Address

declarations.comments: A prism for the `IPv4Address` constructor.
declarations.title: _IPv4Address

declarations.comments:
A generic absolute-or-empty path, used in both hierarchical-part and
relative-parts when an authority component is present. Corresponds to
_path-abempty_ in the spec.

A path value of `/` corresponds to `Path [""]`, an empty path is `Path []`.
declarations.title: Path

declarations.comments:
An absolute path, corresponding to _path-absolute_ in the spec. This path
cannot represent the value `//` - it must either be `/`, or start with a
segment that is not empty, for example: `/something`, `/.`, `/..`. This
type can appear in both hierarchical-part and relative-parts to represent
an absolute path when no authority component is present.

This restriction exists as a value begining with `//` at this point in the
grammar must be an authority, attempting to decide whether a value is an
authority or a path would be ambiguous if `//` paths were allowed. The `//`
path means the same thing as `/` anyway!
declarations.title: PathAbsolute

declarations.comments:
A relative path that doesn't look like a URI scheme, corresponding to
_path-noscheme_ in the spec. This path cannot start with the character
`/`, contain the character `:` before the first `/`, or be entirely empty.
This type can appear in a relative-part when there is no authority
component.
declarations.title: PathNoScheme

declarations.comments:
A relative path, corresponding to _path-rootless_ in the spec. This path
cannot start with the character `/` or be entirely empty. This type can
appear in a hierarchical-part when there is no authority component.
declarations.title: PathRootless

declarations.comments: The port component of a host in a URI.
declarations.title: Port

declarations.comments:
The query component of a URI.

This type treats the entire string as an undifferentiated blob, if you
would like to deal with the common `?key1=value1&key2=value2` format, take
a look at `URI.Extra.QueryPairs`.
declarations.title: Query

declarations.comments: A relative URI. Relative in the sense that it lacks a `Scheme` component.
declarations.title: RelativeRef

declarations.comments:
The "relative part" of a relative reference.  This combines an authority
(optional) with a path value.

When the authority is present a generic path representation can be used,
otherwise there are some restrictions on the path construction to ensure
no ambiguity in parsing (this is per the spec, not a restriction of the
library).
declarations.title: RelativePart

declarations.comments:
The specific path types supported in a relative-part when there is no
authority present. See [`URI.Path.Absolute`](../URI.Path.Absolute) and
[`URI.Path.PathNoScheme`](../URI.Path.PathNoScheme) for an explanation of
these forms.
declarations.title: RelPath

declarations.comments: The scheme part of an absolute URI. For example: `http`, `ftp`, `git`.
declarations.title: Scheme

declarations.comments:
A general purpose absolute URI - similar to `AbsoluteURI` but also admits
a fragment component. An absolute URI can still contain relative paths
but is required to have a `Scheme` component.
declarations.title: URI

declarations.comments:
The "hierarchical part" of a generic or absolute URI. This combines an
authority (optional) with a path value.

When the authority is present a generic path representation can be used,
otherwise there are some restrictions on the path construction to ensure
no ambiguity in parsing (this is per the spec, not a restriction of the
library).
declarations.title: HierarchicalPart

declarations.comments:
The specific path types supported in a hierarchical-part when there is no
authority present. See [`URI.Path.Absolute`](../URI.Path.Absolute) and
[`URI.Path.Rootless`](../URI.Path.Rootless) for an explanation of these
forms.
declarations.title: HierPath

declarations.comments:
The user info part of an `Authority`. For example: `user`, `foo:bar`.

This type treats the entire string as an undifferentiated blob, if you
would like to specifically deal with the `user:password` format, take a
look at `URI.Extra.UserPassInfo`.
declarations.title: UserInfo

declarations.comments: The most general kind of URI, can either be relative or absolute.
declarations.title: URIRef

declarations.comments:
A row type for describing the options fields used by the general URI
parser and printer.

Used as `Record (URIRefOptions userInfo hosts path hierPath relPath query fragment)`
when type anotating an options record.

See below for details of how to use these configuration options.
declarations.title: URIRefOptions

declarations.comments:
A row type for describing the options fields used by the general URI
parser.

Used as `Record (URIRefParseOptions userInfo hosts path hierPath relPath query fragment ())`
when type anotating an options record.

Having this options record allows custom representations to be used for
the URI components. If this is not necessary, `pure` can be used for all
the options aside from `parseHosts`, which will typically be
`HostPortPair.parseHosts pure pure`. See [`URI.HostPortPair`](../URI.HostPortPair)
for more information on the host/port pair parser.
declarations.title: URIRefParseOptions

declarations.comments:
A row type for describing the options fields used by the general URI
printer.

Used as `Record (URIRefPrintOptions userInfo hosts path hierPath relPath query fragment ())`
when type anotating an options record.

As a reverse of the parse options, this specifies how to print values back
from custom representations. If this is not necessary, `id` can be used for
all the options aside from `printHosts`, which will typically be
`HostPortPair.printHosts id id`. See [`URI.HostPortPair`](../URI.HostPortPair)
for more information on the host/port pair printer.
declarations.title: URIRefPrintOptions

declarations.comments: A parser for a general URI.
declarations.title: parser

declarations.comments: A printer for a general URI.
declarations.title: print

declarations.comments:
The user info part of an `Authority`. For example: `user`, `foo:bar`.

This type treats the entire string as an undifferentiated blob, if you
would like to specifically deal with the `user:password` format, take a
look at `URI.Extra.UserPassInfo`.
declarations.title: UserInfo

declarations.comments:
Constructs a user-info value from a string, percent-encoding any characters
that require it. Note that running this on a string that has already had
percent-encoding applied will double-encode it, for those situations use
`unsafeFromString` instead.

``` purescript
fromString "foo" = unsafeFromString "foo"
fromString "foo@bar" = unsafeFromString "foo%40bar"
fromString "foo%40bar" = unsafeFromString "foo%2540bar"
```
declarations.title: fromString

declarations.comments:
Returns the string value for user-info, percent-decoding any characters
that require it.

``` purescript
toString (unsafeFromString "foo") = "foo"
toString (unsafeFromString "foo%40bar") = "foo@bar"
```
declarations.title: toString

declarations.comments:
Constructs a user-info value from a string directly - no percent-encoding
will be applied. This is useful when using a custom encoding scheme for
the query, to prevent double-encoding.
declarations.title: unsafeFromString

declarations.comments:
Returns the string value for user-info without percent-decoding. Only
"unsafe" in the sense that values this produces may need further decoding,
the name is more for symmetry with the `fromString`/`unsafeFromString`
pairing.
declarations.title: unsafeToString

declarations.comments: A parser for the user-info component of a URI.
declarations.title: parser

declarations.comments: A printer for the user-info component of a URI.
declarations.title: print

declarations.comments: The supported user info characters, excluding percent-encodings.
declarations.title: userInfoChar
